bright green stems and siliques (stems less glossy than siliques), lobed plates on stems and siliques, lacks tube-shaped structures on siliques but has them on stems, slender appearance.
bright green stems and siliques, substantially reduced number of lobed plates and tube-shaped structures on the epicuticular wax layer, reduced plant height.
bright green stems and siliques, mainly tube-shaped structures absent on the epicuticular wax layer.
slightly bright green stems and siliques, number of lobed plates and tube-shaped structures on the epicuticular wax layer approach the wild type; often starts as a small rosette but plant recovers.
bright green stems and siliques, substantially reduced number of lobed plates, and dendrite-like structures present on the epicuticular wax layer.

bright green stems and siliques, number of lobed plates and tube-shaped structures on the epicuticular wax layer approach the wild type, reduced plant height (looks like semi-dwarf), somewhat club-like siliques.
yellow-green seedling, lethal.
yellow-green seedling, lethal.
yellow-green embryos and seedlings, lethal.
yellow-green seedling, lethal.
green-yellow shoots.
pale green embryos, green-yellow plants, lethal, segregates male steriles.
chlorate resistance due to a decreased nitrate reductase activity.

chlorate resistant due to reduced nitrate reductase activity, about 20-30 percent of the wild-type level; reduced levels of the nitrate reductase cofactor molybdenum-pterin (Mo Co); sensitive to 0.1mM tungstate; poor growth on nitrate medium.
decreased nitrate-reductase activity, chlorate-resistant.
chlorate resistant due to little or no nitrate reductase activity; reduced levels of the nitrate reductase cofactor molybenum-pterin (Mo Co); dies on nitrate medium.
young leaves and sepals yellow-green.

rosette leaves become chlorotic, wilt and die after more than 3 days exposure to chilling temperatures in the range of 14-4C and can not be rescued after this time by a return to the normal growth temperature; defective in chloroplast protein accumulation at low temperatures.

rosette leaves become chlorotic, wilt and die after more than 3 days exposure to chilling temperatures in the range of 14-4C and can not be rescued after this time by a return to the normal growth temperature; defective in chloroplast protein accumulation at low temperatures.

older rosette leaves become chlorotic, wilt and die when plant is grown at 10C; younger rosette leaves are not affected; plant will eventually bolt and set seed after several weeks at the chilling temperature; chilling sensitive at 18-10C.
eventually bolt and set seed after several weeks at the chilling temperature; chilling sensitive at 18-10C; defective in chloroplast protein accumulation at low temperatures.

older rosette leaves become chlorotic, wilt and die when plant is grown at 10C; younger rosette leaves are not affected; plant will eventually bolt and set seed after several weeks at the chilling temperature; chilling sensitive at 14-10C; defective in chloroplast protein accumulation at low temperatures.

rosette leaves develop chlorotic patches which are not always contiguous and veins remain green when transferred to 10C; plant will eventually bolt and set seed after several weeks at the chilling temperature; chilling sensitive at 10C.

rosette leaves develop chlorotic patches which are not always contiguous and veins remain green when transferred to 10C; plant will eventually bolt and set seed after several weeks at the chilling temperature; chilling sensitive at 18-10C.

rosette leaves develop chlorotic patches which are not always contiguous and veins remain green when transferred to 10C; plant will eventually bolt and set seed after several weeks at the chilling temperature; chilling sensitive at 18-10C.

rosette leaves develop chlorotic patches which are not always contiguous and veins remain green when transferred to 10C; plant will eventually bolt and set seed after several weeks at the chilling temperature; chilling sensitive at 10C.
yellow-green weak plant.

Disease-resistant mutant; strong allele; constitutive activation of Systemic Acquired Resistance (SAR) pathway; lacks spontaneous hypersensitive response (HR) cell death; high levels of salicylic acid (SA) accumulation; expression of constitutive PR-1/luciferase activity; kanamycin resistant (50 ug/ml).

Disease-resistant mutant; intermediate allele; constitutive activation of Systemic Acquired Resistance (SAR) pathway; lacks spontaneous hypersensitive response (HR) cell death; high levels of salicylic acid (SA) accumulation; expression of constitutive PR-1/luciferase activity; kanamycin resistant (50 ug/ml).

Disease-resistant mutant; strong allele; constitutive activation of Systemic Acquired Resistance (SAR) pathway; lacks spontaneous hypersensitive response (HR) cell death; high levels of salicylic acid (SA) accumulation; expression of constitutive PR-1/luciferase activity; kanamycin resistant (50 ug/ml).

Disease-resistant mutant; strong allele; constitutive activation of Systemic Acquired Resistance (SAR) pathway; lacks spontaneous hypersensitive response (HR) cell death; high levels of salicylic acid (SA) accumulation; expression of constitutive PR-1/luciferase activity; kanamycin resistant (50 ug/ml).

Disease-resistant mutant; strong allele; constitutive activation of Systemic Acquired Resistance (SAR) pathway; lacks spontaneous hypersensitive response (HR) cell death; high levels of salicylic acid (SA) accumulation; expression of constitutive PR-1/luciferase activity; kanamycin resistant (50 ug/ml).

Disease-resistant mutant; weak allele; constitutive activation of Systemic Acquired Resistance (SAR) pathway;  lacks spontaneous hypersensitive response (HR) cell death; high levels of salicylic acid (SA) accumulation; expression of constitutive PR-1/luciferase activity; kanamycin resistant (50 ug/ml).

Disease-resistant mutant; strong allele; constitutive activation of Systemic Acquired Resistance (SAR) pathway; lacks spontaneous hypersensitive response (HR) cell death; high levels of salicylic acid (SA) accumulation; expression of constitutive PR-1/luciferase activity; kanamycin resistant (50 ug/ml).

defective in the induction of ethylene biosynthesis by cytokinin; lacks the ethylene-mediated triple response in the presence of cytokinin; subtle effects on the morphology of adult plants (yellowish areas at the leaf margins); reduced shoot initiation in tissue culture and reduction of anthocyanin in light grown seedlings in response to cytokinin.

defective in the induction of ethylene biosynthesis by cytokinin; lacks the ethylene-mediated triple response in the presence of cytokinin; disrupted ethylene biosynthesis in multiple conditions; pleiotropic effects in response to  cytokinin: reduced anthocyanin content, shorter siliques than wt and somewhat club-shaped; reduced chlorophyll content in leaves.

defective in the induction of ethylene biosynthesis by cytokinin; lacks the ethylene-mediated triple response in the presence of cytokinin; subtle effects on the morphology of adult plants (slightly larger than wt); does not disrupt ethylene biosynthesis under any other conditions, nor does it disrupt any other cytokinin responses.
constitutive expression of defense related genes

Constitutive expression of the marker gene PR-1::luciferase in the absence of pathogen infection; enhanced resistance to the necrotrophic pathogen Botrytis cinerea; cir3-mediated resistance to B. cinerea is dependent on accumulated salicylic acid and a functional EIN2 protein.
semi-dwarf; small plants with small rosettes.
semi-dwarf; round, dark green leaves.
Angustifolia, Compacta
Asymmetric leaves. Width of sheet plate more length. Compact? Semi-dwarf.
seedling insensitive to 2mM cesium, reduced uptake of Rb-86 and P-32, lacks trichomes on stems and leaves, some rudimentary trichomes in leaf margins.

Faster completion of seed germination at low temperature (10C) compared to wild type; transparent testa phenotype (somewhat pale brown seeds due to reduced levels of brown pigment in seed coat); hypersensitive to abscicic acid, gibberellic acid and paclobutrazol.

Callus-induced roots from the mutant displayed the mutant phenotype when they grew under restrictive conditions. All the mutants responded to a gravitropic stimulus in a manner similar to wild type although the change of the direction of growth was slower than wild type.
Male sterile.
When grown on media containing 0.5% sucrose, the mutant had reduced root length but no apparent radial cell expansion.
Defective in chloroplast development; pale green plants through life.

Defective in chloroplast development; very pale at germination; virescent and slow-greening; young photosynthetic tissues emerge pale, but gradually chloroplast development and almost full greening occur; center of rosettes, edges of leaves towards the petiole and young inflorescences are pale.
Defective in chloroplast development; poor germination, pale green and slightly purple seedlings; later leaves have a reticulate pattern with veins greener than the interveinal regions of leaves.

Various cytokinesis defects in both vegetative and reproductive organs reflected in partial or missing cell walls (stomata), cell wall protrusions, increased number of nuclei per cell, enlarged cells (stomata and pollen), reduced cell number and resulting in defects in leaf and flower shape and development.
Impaired root hair development; often display very short stumps or collapsed root hairs; mostly very short root hairs.
Root hairs have mostly very short root hairs, indicating a defect in the transition to rapid tip growth, which is required to fully develop the hair structure.

Impaired root hair development; often display very short stumps or collapsed root hairs; root hairs are often wavy, have an irregular hair diameter or are collapsed; sometimes develop bulbous structures at the root hair base.
Root hairs display very short stumps or collapsed root hairs.  Root hairs are often wavy, with an irregular hair diameter.  Sometimes develop bulbous structures at the root hair base.
Impaired root hair development; often display very short stumps or collapsed root hairs; root hairs are often wavy, have an irregular hair diameter or are collapsed.
Root hairs display very short stumps or collapsed root hairs.  Root hairs have an irregular hair diameter or are collapsed.

Impaired root hair development; seedlings form root hairs in a regular pattern, but significantly shorter than in the wild type; develops two different types of root hair structures: relatively short stumps with a clearly wider diameter than wild type hairs and longer hair structures which are wider in the lower half of the root hair proper while the upper half is wild type like

Root hairs are very regular but significantly shorter than in the wild type.  Develops two different types of root hair structures: relatively short stumps with a clearly wider diameter than wt hairs and longer hair structures which are wider in the lower half of the root hair proper while the upper half is wt like.

Impaired root hair development; often display very short stumps or collapsed root hairs; hairs are often wavy, have an irregular hair diameter or are collapsed; sometimes develop bulbous structures at the root hair base; application of exogenous auxin and ethylene suppress aberrant root hair phenotype
Root hairs display very short stumps or collapsed root hairs.  Root hairs are often wavy, with an irregular hair diameter.  Sometimes develop bulbous structures at the root hair base.

Broad spectrum of disease resistance to oomycete, bacterial and fungal pathogens. Mutants exhibit dwarfism and are resistant to Pseudomonas syringae pv tomato, and to the powdery mildew pathogen, Golovinomyces orontii and shows enhanced defense gene expression.

Broad spectrum of disease resistance to oomycete, bacterial and fungal pathogens.  Mutants are dwarf, resistant to Psuedomonas syringae pv tomato, and to the powdery mildew pathogen, Golovinomyces orontii with an enhanced defense gene expression.
Resistant to downy mildew fungus Hyaloperonospora parasitica. There was significant hyphal growth but haustoria were not formed in all adjacent plant cells. Plants show normal plant development.
road leaves with scalloped leaf margins, late flowering.

affects the expression of CAB (photosystem II type I chlorophyll a/b-binding proteins) genes in the dark, accumulation of endogenous CAB mRNA is ca. 3.5 times greater than wild type; has no effect on the expression of RBCS genes; obvious morphological changes are absent in the dark with plants being normally etiolated; under long days, no visible difference from wild type; under short days, plants are shorter and have less than half of the fresh weight of wild type.

affects the expression of CAB (photosystem II type I chlorophyll a/b-binding proteins) genes in the dark; accumulation of endogenous CAB mRNA is ca. 3.2 times greater than wild type; has no effect on the expression of RBCS genes; obvious morphological changes absent in the dark with plants being normally etiolated; under long days, no visible difference from wild type; under short days, plants are shorter and have less than half of the fresh weight of the wild type.

Under long-day conditions, all the developmental phases  of the drm1 mutant are severely retarded, and a period of  109 d is needed from sowing to flowering compared to 42  d for the wild type. Its germination  rate is significantly lower and its germination speed  is 3-4 d slower compared to the wild-type. drm1 produces significantly more inflorescences, but fertility is severely reduced due to unusual shorter stamens. Mutants also have abnormal numbers of petals (5 or 6) and stamens.
Defective in DST-mediated mRNA degradation

weak allele; aberrant leaf morphology; no clear distinction between the petiole and the leaf blade; leaves are narrow and pointed; with elongated appearance, small, dark-green, irregularly serrated and curled dawn in the apix; lacks trichomes on stems and leaves, some trichomes in leaf margins.

weak allele; aberrant leaf morphology; no clear distinction between the petiole and the leaf blade; leaves are narrow and pointed, with elongated appearance, small, dark-green, irregularly serrated and curled dawn in the apix; somewhat late flowering; abnormal inflorescence bearing flowers with reduced fertility; bushy plants; lacks trichomes on stems and leaves, some trichomes in leaf margins.

weak allele; aberrant leaf morphology; no clear distinction between the petiole and the leaf blade; leaves are narrow and pointed, with elongated appearance, dark-green, irregularly serrated and curled dawn in the apix; somewhat late flowering; abnormal inflorescence bearing flowers with reduced fertility; bushy plants; lacks trichomes on stems and leaves, some trichomes in leaf margins.

strong allele; aberrant leaf morphology; long and thin petiols; leaves are dark-green, with gross irregular outhgrowths of leaf tissue along the leaf edges, giving an irregular leaf shape appearance, leaf edges curled down and torted; asymmetric leaf surface; occassionally two leaves come out from a petiol or a complete leaf from another leaf; abnormal inflorescence bearing esterile flowers; bushy plants.
increased susceptibility to the moderately virulent bacterial pathogen Pseudomonas syringae pv. maculicola strain ES4326.
increased susceptibility to the moderately virulent bacterial pathogen Pseudomonas syringae pv. maculicola strain ES4326; altered leaf morphology (smaller and serrated).

exhibits enhanced disease susceptibility to the virulent bacterial pathogen Pseudomonas syringae pv maculicola ES4326; unique patterns of susceptibility to a variety of bacterial pathogens; ability to activate pathogenesis-related PR-1 gene expression after pathogen attack; no defects in the hypersensitive response (HR); and exhibits at least a partial systemic acquired resistance (SAR) response.
no longer expressing rolB gene silencing; kanamycin resistant; wild type in appearance; some of first flowers may be sterile.
enhanced silencing of a 35S::rolb transgene
no longer expressing rolB gene silencing; kanamycin resistant; wild type in appearance; some of first flowers may be sterile.
semi-dominant mutation, ethylene insensitive.
Strong allele; erecta-like inflorescence with flowers clustered together at the inflorescence apex, resembling the erecta (er) mutant;  exhibit shorter siliques than the wt; reduced  apical dominance

Strong allele; erecta-like inflorescence with flowers clustered together at the inflorescence apex, resembling the erecta (er) mutant;  exhibit shorter siliques than the wt; reduced  apical dominance; absence of trichomes on leaves and stems, some trichomes on leaf margins.

Strong allele; erecta-like inflorescence with flowers clustered together at the inflorescence apex, resembling the erecta (er) mutant;  short and wide siliques that have a blunt tip; highly reduced fertility;  short plants; heterozygote plants display intermediate phenotype between wt and elk5.

Impaired root hair development; forms root hairs that branch from the enlarged base or the hair proper and seem to randomly change growth direction.
Impaired root hair development; root hairs appear like the wild type except for the reduced length.
Impaired root hair development; seedlings form root hairs in a regular pattern; length of the hair proper is not affected, but side branches develop from the enlarged bases.
Impaired root hair development; seedlings develop root hairs of wild type length but with a clearly increased diameter in the lower part of the root hair.
Root hairs form in a regular pattern.  Length of the hair proper is not affected but side branches develop from the enlarged bases.
reduced elongation of oleic acid (18:1); reduced levels of long-chain fatty acids in seed storage lipids, especially enucic (22:1) and eicosenoic (20:1) acids; increased levels of oleic acid (18:1).
late flowering, unaffected by vernalization, increased number of rosette leaves.

no transmission through the female gametophyte, but does transmit through the male gametophyte; 100% penetrant in the female gametophyte; developmental arrest just before polar nuclei fusion stage but after three rounds of mitosis and cellularization, not affecting many fundamental cellular processes such as mitosis, vacuole formation, nuclear migration, and cellularization; altered segregation pattern (self-pollination of a heterozygous produces heterozygous and wt progeny in an approx. 1:1 ratio); individuals can be identified by opening siliques and screening for 50% seed set.

reduced (at least 56%) transmission through the female gametophyte, but does transmit through the male gametophyte; partially penetrant in the female gametophyte; developmental arrest at the one-nucleate stage; altered segregation pattern (self-pollination of a heterozygous produces heterozygous and wt progeny in an approx. 1:1 ratio); individuals can be identified by opening siliques and screening for 50% seed set or by selecting the progeny on kanamycin.

reduced transmission (at least 56%) through both the female and male gametophyte; partially penetrant in the female gametophyte; developmental arrest at the one-nucleate stage, affecting microgametogenesis; altered segregation pattern (self-pollination of a heterozygous produces heterozygous and wt progeny in an approx. 1:1 ratio); individuals can be identified by opening siliques and screening for 50% seed set or by selecting the progeny on kanamycin.

no transmission through both the female and male gametophyte; 100% penetrant in the female gametophyte; developmental arrest at the polar nuclei fusion and cellularization stages, abnormal cellular morphology; altered segregation pattern (self-pollination of a heterozygous produces heterozygous and wt progeny in an approx. 1:1 ratio); individuals can be identified by opening siliques and screening for 50% seed set or by selecting the progeny on kanamycin

strong allele; floral defects in the first and third whorls; sepals fuse partially or completely along their margins, with more extended frequency in apical flowers; number of stamens in basal flowers is increased and two stamens often displays partial fusion; in more apical flowers the frequency of extra stamens and of stamen-stamen fusion is decreased; margins of cauline leaves and the cotyledons have similar abnormalities of fusion, one or both margins of one or more cauline leaves are attached inappropriately at their base to the stem of the inflorescence.

strong allele; semidominant; variable floral defects in all 4 whorls; fusions between organs in a whorl or in adjacent whorls; fused stamens, stamen mosaic organs, and reduced stamen-like organs, which severity increases acropetally; slight increase in sepal number and decrease in petal number, narrow sepals and petals, sepals also varies widely in size and shape; surface of gynoecia appears normal, but there is some reduction in fertility; disrupted phyllotaxy of flowers and initiate more flowers at a time than wild type.

slightly weak allele; floral defects primarily in the first and third whorls; variable number of partially or completely fused sepals and stamens; small increase in stamen number in basal flowers; minor defects observed in the second whorl;the gynoecia displays a bulge in the apical part of the valves below the stigma and exhibits slightly decreased fertility with a corresponding decrease in silique elongation; non floral defects that alters cotyledon growth, cauline leaf development and inflorescence internode elongation (plants are shorter than wt).
club-shaped siliques, apical portions of main inflorescence possibly fasciated.

gar1 is semi-dominant or dominant, depending on GAI genotype; gar1 restores gibberellin responsiveness in gibberellin insensitive (gai) mutants; also restores normal stature, flowering time, apical dominance and seed germination to gai mutants (gai phenotype: semi-dominant mutation with reduced stature, reduced apical dominance, and reduced seed germination; delayed flowering in short days); an phenotype: narrow leaves, increased number of rosette leaves, slightly twisted siliques; gar1 closely linked to gai - not genetically separable.
essentially normal growth (gai dwarf phenotype is largely suppressed); an phenotype: narrow leaves, slightly twisted siliques.

Small and dark-green rosette leaves; short roots; delayed flowering time; reduced plant stature with increased axillary branches; reduced apical dominance; female sterility: severely aberrant flowers with a remarkably reduced and completely sterile gynoecium. Glucose-insensitive.
Over-expression of GA-responsive GASA promoter reporters (hence goe)
Overexpression of GA-responsive GASA promoter reporters (hence goe), paclobutrazol resistant, GA-hypersensitive, kanamycin resistant
Reverse gravitropic response to gravistimulation at 4C in both inflorescence shoots and hypocotyls. The phenotype is apparent after the plants have been returned to room temperature.
Enhanced response to gravistimulation at 4C in both inflorescence shoots and hypocotyls. The phenotype is apparent after the plants have been returned to room temperature.

plant appears to have spaces in the xylem in a position that is normally occupied by xylem elements; irregular pattern of secondary cell wall formation in the interfascicular region, with some cells possessing very thick secondary cell wall, with other cells failing to initiate any kind of secondary cell wall.
short plant, gray-green leaves.

Glutamine sensing regulator; increased sensitivity to methylamine (MA), methyl-glutamine accumulates in the presence of MA; growth of plants are markedly reduced, yellow seedlings with reduced chloroplast number per cell.

dominant mutation; no visible phenotype when grown in soil; when grown in vitro, exhibits epinastic growth of leaves; root growth is slightly more sensitive to IAA inhibition of elongation; gup1-1 leads to enhanced kanamycin resistance in the AIR1-8 background via an nptII gene under control of a tobacco GST promoter; also shows an increased mRNA level of GST5 from Arabidopsis (designated At103-1a in van der Kop et. al. 1999); kanamycin resistant.
no visible phenotype when grown in soil; when grown in vitro, exhibits epinastic growth of leaves; root growth is slightly more sensitive to IAA inhibition of elongation

Distorted segregation, reduced transmission through the male gametophyte, does not appreciably affect the female gametophyte; pollen tube growth in ovary is short, but pollen tubes target the ovules they reach.

Distorted segregation, reduced transmission through the male gametophyte, does not appreciably affect the female gametophyte; pollen tube growth path appears normal, yet tubes fail to enter the micropyle.

Distorted segregation, reduced transmission through the male gametophyte, does not appreciably affect the female gametophyte; pollen tube growth in ovary is short, but pollen tubes target the ovules they reach.

Distorted segregation, reduced transmission through the male gametophyte, does not appreciably affect the female gametophyte; completely disrupted male functions, siring no BastaR progeny when crossed to wild type; disrupted pollen grain development.
Distorted segregation, affecting the male gametophyte and the female gametophyte, decreasing, but not eliminating, the function of both gametophytes; pollen tubes fail to leave the septum.

Distorted segregation, reduced transmission through the female gametophyte;  mild penetration; no obvious defect in pollen grain development, pollen tube growth through the style and pollen tube growth or guidance in the ovary.

Distorted segregation, affecting the male gametophyte and the female gametophyte, decreasing, but not eliminating, the function of both gametophytes; short pollen tube growth, failing to exit the style.
Distorted segregation, reduced transmission through the male gametophyte, does not appreciably affect the female gametophyte; short pollen tube growth, failing to exit the style.
Distorted segregation, affecting the male gametophyte and the female gametophyte, decreasing, but not eliminating, the function of both gametophytes; pollen tubes fail to leave the septum.
Distorted segregation, male gametophyte and female gametophyte are severely affected; pollen tube growth in ovary is short, but pollen tubes target the ovules they reach.
Distorted segregation, reduced transmission through the male gametophyte, does not appreciably affect the female gametophyte; pollen tube growth is chaotic in the ovary.

Distorted segregation, affecting the male gametophyte and the female gametophyte, decreasing, but not eliminating, the function of both gametophytes; no obvious defect in pollen grain development, pollen tube growth through the style and pollen tube growth or guidance in the ovary.

Distorted segregation, reduced transmission through the male gametophyte, does not appreciably affect the female gametophyte; pollen tube growth path appears normal, yet tubes fail to enter the micropyle.

Distorted segregation, affecting the male gametophyte (MG) and the female gametophyte (FG),  complete elimination of the function of the FG while having a mild impact on MG function; pollen tube growth is chaotic in the ovary.

Distorted segregation, reduced transmission through the male gametophyte (MG), does not appreciably affect the female gametophyte (FG); strong, but not complete impact on pollen function; short pollen tube growth, failing to exit the style.

Distorted segregation, reduced transmission through the female gametophyte (FG); nearly completely penetrant; no obvious defect in pollen grain development, pollen tube growth through the style and pollen tube growth or guidance in the ovary.

Distorted segregation, reduced transmission through the male gametophyte, does not appreciably affect the female gametophyte; strong, but not complete impact on pollen function; short pollen tube growth, failing to exit the style.

Distorted segregation, affecting the male gametophyte (MG) and the female gametophyte (FG), complete elimination of the function of the FG while having a mild impact on MG function; pollen tube growth path appears normal, yet tubes fail to enter the micropyle.

Distorted segregation, reduced transmission through the male gametophyte, does not appreciably affect the female gametophyte; pollen tube growth in ovary is short, but pollen tubes target the ovules they reach.
Distorted segregation, male gametophyte and female gametophyte are severely affected; short pollen tube growth, failing to exit the style.

Distorted segregation, reduced transmission through the male gametophyte, does not appreciably affect the female gametophyte; strong, but not complete impact on pollen function; short pollen tube growth, failing to exit the style.
Mutants display stunted growth, reduced plant height and small rosettes.  Their leaves are small and narrow with lobed blades and disrupted tissue organization.

high cambial activity leading to a continuous ring of vascular tissues; leaves twisted and smaller; reduction in internode length; increased number of secondary stems; delay in development; reduced cell size; alterations in root formation

Other than the pollen abnormality there is no visible phenotype. Exine structures collapsed, in which the tectum has disappeared and hte bacula was deformed into a globular protrusion. A number of microspores collapsed adn their contents leaked into locules.Small, distorted mature pollen grains.
Defects are specific to pollen. Pollen tectum formation is perturbed. Tectum is broken, exposing the baculae. Overall swize, shape and fertility of pollen grains were comparable to WT.

Other than the pollen abnormality there is no visible phenotype. Exine structures collapsed, in which no normal tectum or bacula were identified. A number of microspores collapsed and their contents leaked into locules. Small, distorted mature pollen grains. Pollen is sterile.
Defect specific to pollen exine layer. Dense baculae and a small, fractured tectum. Some pollen grains were distorted. pollen is fully fertile

Defect specific to pollen exine layer. Abnormal baculae distribution. Higher number of baculae than WT. Tectum barely visible and nexine I looks discontinuous. A thick layer between nexine I and plasma membrane, where nexine II and intine will form, was also observed. Some distorted pollen grains observed. Fully fertile.

unable to support normal growth of the powdery mildew pathogen, Erysiphe cichoracearum; does not constitutively express PR1, does not form lesions in response to pathogen attack; highly specific resistance for powdery mildew, susceptible even to a closely related powdery mildew Erysiphe orontii; resistance is correlated with approximately 1.7-fold more PR1 message than wild type, suggesting that the salicylic acid pathway may play a role in mediating resistance; pleiotropic phenotype, defective in pollen tube growth or guidance.

unable to support normal growth of the powdery mildew pathogen, Erysiphe cichoracearum; does not constitutively express PR1; does not form lesions in response to pathogen attack; highly specific resistance for powdery mildew; accumulates lower levels of PR1 mRNA than wild type; pleiotropic phenotype, conditional dwarf.
embryo defective; embryos are radially swollen with reduced cellulose content; mature seeds have somewhat peanut-fruit shape; segregation distortion due to a reduced transmission through pollen.
embryo defective; embryos are radially swollen with reduced cellulose content; mature seeds have somewhat peanut-fruit shape; segregation distortion due to a reduced transmission through pollen.
embryo defective; embryos are radially swollen with reduced cellulose content; mature seeds have somewhat peanut-fruit shape; segregation distortion due to a very reduced transmission through pollen.
light green cotyledons and leaves, numerous short rosette inflorescences, inflorescences with one or more umbels (cluster of flowers originating from about the same point).

Defective in acid phosphatase (APase) secretion but otherwise respond normally to phosohorus (P) deficiency; reduced APase activity from root exudates and other tissues; has 49%, 38%, and 37% less specific APase activity in exudates, roots, and shoots, respectively; defective in the activity of some APase Activity Isoforms; when provided inorganic P in solution, plants accumulate P normally, but when grown in a substrate containing organic P, plants accumulate less shoot P.
broad, round leaves with short petioles.
reduced dormancy; does not require GA; high capacity for dark germination; freshly harvested seeds will germinate; embryo determined (not a maternal effect).

Double mutant, reduced seed dormancy determined by the embryo; increased ability to germinate as freshly harvested seeds compared to each of the monogenic mutants; cumulative effect of the individual mutations suggest that they control different pathways; high capacity to germinate in darkness.

Double mutant, reduced seed dormancy determined by the embryo; ability to germinate as freshly harvested seeds; lack of additive effect of each of the individual monogenic mutants; single mutants show rather different pleiotropic effects; high capacity to germinate in darkness.

Double mutant, reduced seed dormancy determined by the embryo; increased ability to germinate as freshly harvested seeds compared to each of the monogenic mutants; cumulative effect of the individual mutations suggest that they control different pathways; high capacity to germinate in darkness.

Double mutant, reduced seed dormancy determined by the embryo; ability to germinate as freshly harvested seeds; lack of additive effect of each of the individual monogenic mutants; single mutants show rather different pleiotropic effects; high capacity to germinate in darkness.

Double mutant, reduced seed dormancy determined by the embryo; increased ability to germinate as freshly harvested seeds compared to each of the monogenic mutants; cumulative effect of the individual mutations suggest that they control different pathways; high capacity to germinate in darkness.

Reduced seed dormancy determined by the embryo; ability to germinate as freshly harvested seeds; high capacity to germinate in darkness; reduced sensitivity to gibberellin biosynthesis inhibitors compared to wt (indicating a reduced gibberellin requirement);  plants exhibit a slightly darker green color and a flattened top of the inflorescence compared to wt.

Double mutant, reduced seed dormancy determined by the embryo; increased ability to germinate as freshly harvested seeds compared to each of the monogenic mutants; cumulative effect of the individual mutations suggest that they control different pathways; weak capacity  to germinate in darkness.

Seedlings have shorter primary roots and increased numbers of lateral roots compared to Nossen wild type.  Adults were indistinguishable from wild type in terms of shoot length and secondary inflorescence formation.  Hypocotyl and root IBA basipetal transport are decreased.  Root acropetal IBA transport is increased.

Seedlings show strong swelling behind the root tip and also hypocotyl swelling; the phenotype is present at 20C but enhanced at 30C; floral stigma often protrudes beyond much reduced petals; modest reduction in cellulose; increased monosaccharides derived from non-cellulosic polysaccharides.
yellow seeds, kanamycin resistant and hygromycin sensitive.

Short or absent integuments on ovules, growth of both integuments arrest shortly after initiation; subtle pleiotropic effects observed in the gynoecia (pistils) and sepals of flowers: most pistils have a cleft stigma in the axis of one of the valves, valve on the cleft side of the stigma commonly bears an outgrowth ('bump'), sepal margins are jagged, consisting of few small rounded cells, especially toward the tips; complete female sterility; slightly slow growth rate.
Female-sterile, aberrant ovules, short integuments, cleft stigma.
Unbranched trichomes.
Cumulative phenotype compared to both single mutants.
Phenotype not described.
Produces mostly two-branched trichomes.
Cumulative phenotype compared to both single mutants.
Nearly 60% of trichomes are unbranched.
Produces approximately 80% unbranched and 20% two-branched trichomes.
Severely stunted and infertile.
Most double mutant plants have no branch points (about 37% have one branch point).
Does not produce unbranched trichomes.
Produces mostly two-branched trichomes.
Slow-growing plant with decreased fertility.

Trichomes show strikingly different proportions with a long stalk and two short branches. The branch point is slightly lower than the secondary branch point in wild type but significantly higher than in an mutants. The two branches are arranged with an angle of 85 degrees. No obvious orientation of the two branches relative to the leaf axis is observed.
Develops between two and four branch points.
Trichomes have two or three branch points.

suppression of rate of elongation in rapidly elongating cells; slow rate of cell number increase in roots; organs shorter and thinner than wild type; leaves sometimes dark; cotyledons prone to anthocyanin production when grown on plates; small, somewhat asymmetric, curled and twisted leaves; rosette 2.5 cm. diameter; somewhat reduced apical dominance, depending on growth conditions; growth of roots, but not cultured or regenerating cells, much less responsive to cytokinins than WT
elongated, altered suspensor; white seeds; white embryo; 21.8% mutant; 53.6% aborted seeds in top half of silique.
No visible phenotype.
Male sterile.

Produces a significant number of three-branched trichomes. However, the branches may not always be of the correct size or shape, and one or more of the branches might be twisted, bent or shorter than their wild-type counterparts. The short stalk defect remains the same as in the zwi-3 single mutant.
Trichomes have more branches than those of wild type plants.

Produces a significant number of three-branched trichomes. However, the branches may not always be of the correct size or shape, and one or more of the branches might be twisted, bent or shorter than their wild-type counterparts. The short stalk defect remains the same as in the zwi-3 single mutant.
Fails to suppress the zwi phenotype.
Fails to suppress the zwi phenotype.
No visible phenotype.

Produces a significant number of three-branched trichomes. However, the branches may not always be of the correct size or shape, and one or more of the branches might be twisted, bent or shorter than their wild-type counterparts. The short stalk defect remains the same as in the zwi-3 single mutant.
true leaves of unsupplemented plants yellow-green, somewhat variegated.
embryo defective; terminal embryo phenotype: preglobular stage.
embryo defective; terminal embryo phenotype: preglobular stage.
embryo defective; terminal embryo phenotype: transition stage.
embryo defective; terminal embryo phenotype: preglobular/globular stage.
Leaves are larger, rounder and curve upward compared to wild type. Leaf lamina are cup shaped. Increased branding of trichomes.

enlarged endosperm nuclei early in development, the number of endosperm nuclei and the extent of nuclear enlargement is somewhat reduced relative to ttn1, endosperm remains in a free nuclear state throghout development, average number of nucleoli is increased; mutant embryo is composed of several small cells; immature seeds are filled with a watery endosperm and have a glassy appearance, small seeds, does not contain the patches of green tissue (enlarged masses of endosperm cytoplasm) found in ttn1 seeds; embryo lethal, cellular degeneration of the embryo begins earlier in development than in ttn1 seeds, often around the heart stage; developmental arrest of embryos occurs at preglobular stage; white seeds prior to dessication; 28.1% mutant seeds in heterozygous siliques; 48.7% aborted seeds in top half of silique
embryo defective; enlarged endosperm nuclei, immature seeds are filled with a watery endosperm and have a glassy appearance.

Incomplete penetrance and highly variable phenotypein mutant embryos. About 8 % of seeds contain embryos that display suspensor proliferation or polyembryony;  Some twin embryos are viable and germinate.  In addition to twinning, some embryos show variable defects in the embryo proper early in embryogenesis.  Cotyledon defects are present in about 10% of embryos/seedlings and occur independent of twinning. Defects in cotyledons/leaf organization do not extend into post-embryonic development beyond the first leaf pair. Mutant phenotype(s) appears to be embryo-specific.

Reduced expression of phosphoribosylanthranilate transferase, a tryptophan biosynthetic enzyme; defective in a wide range of defence responses; after infection with Pseudomonas syringae or Botrytis cinerea, the expression of genes regulated by both the salicylic acid and jasmonic acid/ethylene pathways is reduced in ups1 compared with wild type; greatly reduced  Camalexin accumulation after infection with these two pathogens, as well as after amino acid starvation or oxidative stress; reactive oxygen species (ROS)-mediated gene expression is also compromised indicating that this mutant is defective in signalling pathways activated in response to both biotic and abiotic stress.

strong allele; valine resistant; decreased sensitivity of acetolactate synthase (ALS) to the branched-chain amino acids, valine, leucine and isoleucine; lacks trichomes on stems and leaves, some trichomes in leaf margins.
somewhat compact plants; numerous, round, dark-green rosette leaves; short plants.
dark green, round rosette leaves.
dark green and round rosette leaves, 4.5 m.u. from gl-1.
Increase in free-maltose content in leaves.
Reduction in chlorophyll a and b content (7% and 34%, respectively).
Reduction in free-sugar content (glucose, fructose and lactose).
lacks trichomes on stems and leaves, virescent (yellowish plants), erecta phenotype.
yellow seedling lethal, heterozygote light green.

first one or two leaves transformed into cotyledons (smaller than cotyledons, often irregular in shape, have few or no trichomes and have a simple venation pattern); true cotyledons often misshappen; small rosettes; reduced plant height; inflorescence stem lacks epicuticular wax (cer phenotype); flower buds open prematurely; reduced female fertility; delayed embryogenesis at globular-to-heart transition.

first one or two leaves transformed into cotyledons (smaller than cotyledons, irregular in shape, have few or no trichomes and have a simple venation pattern); true cotyledons slightly misshappen; semi-sterile due to poor pollen production or increased carpel number preventing carpel fusion;  delayed embryogenesis at globular-to-heart transition.
yellow-green cotyledons, leaf margins yellow, small plants.
yellow-green cotyledons, leaf margins yellow; narrow leaves.
yellow-green cotyledons, leaf margins yellow; delayed flowering
yellow-green cotyledons, leaf margins yellow; delayed flowering (ca. 3-4x), large rosettes with numerous rounded leaves; lacks trichomes on stems and leaves, some trichomes in leaf margins.
yellowish flower buds; yellow-gray sharp leaves.
